captions.text:
On the surface, this video features an unbelievably
talented bear performing all kinds of tricks.

On top of that, this is probably the cutest
friendship I've ever seen

comments.author: Jedi Skillz

comments.text:
The typical "animal lover" has no problem with dogs being trained to do 
tricks but when he sees a bear or another animal doing similar tricks he 
gets hysterical and starts accusing total strangers of cruelty to animals. 
There are HUNDREDS of dog training schools all over the US, but when a 
Russian guy decides to teach his pet bear a couple of tricks, the "animal 
lover" goes bezerk!  He thinks that bears would be happier in the 
wilderness where they would suffer from the harsh weather conditions and 
have to hunt and kill other animals in order to survive. Yes, living in a 
forest surrounded by wild aggressive animals and having to endure hunger 
for days is less stressful than having to do a couple of easy tricks for a 
living, right? The fact of the matter is that bears are HAPPIER among 
humans than among wild wolves and boars. Dancing bears are part of the 
Russian folklore. And a beautiful part I might add. NO ONE has the right to 
tell us what to do with our bears. There are no signs of violence on the 
bear in this video. So unless you have irrefutable evidence that said bear 
has been tormented by its owner, shut the..... up! ﻿

comments.author: Rony Ron

comments.text:
Haven't you ever read about Winnipeg the bear?  She was an orphaned baby 
black bear who was bought for $20 in 1914 by a Lt. Harry Colebourn while he 
was en route to meet his regiment in Quebec.  He smuggled Winnipeg on board 
his ship and she was adopted as the unofficial regiment mascot.  When they 
were scheduled to ship out to France, Harry arranged to have Winnipeg stay 
at the London Zoo, where she ended up staying.  Throughout her life, she 
was adored and treated with nothing but kindness by Lt. Harry, his fellow 
soldiers, and everyone at the zoo.  Winnie was so friendly and playful that 
the son of A.A. Milne changed the name of his stuffed bear from 'Edward 
Bear' to "Winnie the Pooh."  Winnie was not a slave, she was a beloved 
international celebrity and has a series of books and endless media 
dedicated to her even now, 100 years after she was born.

comments.author: Panz3rGr3nadier

comments.text:
+Panz3rGr3nadier You're saying it's a fact, and maybe you're right. But I 
would like to ask you your qualifications for making such a statement. Are 
you a qualified wild animal trainer, or have you done extensive research? 
If it's the latter, point me to some of your reputable sources. Otherwise, 
you're making bold statements and then have no way to actually back up 
anything you say. 

I'm not saying you're wrong, but you better be able to prove that you're 
right. Otherwise, it's just your personal assumption, and you have no 
authority in the matter.
